com.pump.debug

Class PanicDialogPrompt

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.pump.debug.PanicDialogPrompt
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    AWTPanicListener

    public class PanicDialogPrompt
extends java.lang.Object
implements AWTPanicListener
    This controversial class launches a new process to ask the user if they want to try to abort the event dispatch thread (by calling Thread.stop()).

    There are several legitimate reasons to disparage this class:

    • Thread.stop() has been deprecated for ages, and is unsafe.
    • Launching another process is a tacky solution.
    • The dialog that results is hard for a user to understand.

    ... and the list goes on. That being said: this class has saved my program before. (That is: the AWT thread was locked -- because of my own programming blunders -- and this class perked up and restored control for me. As a result I didn't lose saved work!)

      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      static void askToStopAWTThread(java.lang.String applicationName)
      This launches another process to prompt the user to cancel the current activity.
      void AWTPanic(java.lang.String applicationName) 
      static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
      Pass the name of an application as the argument, and this main() method prompts the user with a dialog asking them if they want to abort whatever that application is currently doing.
      static void stopAWTThread()
      This uses the unsafe Thread.stop() method on the AWT thread to try to regain control of the application.

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)

      • AWTPanic

        public void AWTPanic(java.lang.String applicationName)
        Specified by:
        AWTPanic in interface AWTPanicListener

      • askToStopAWTThread

        public static void askToStopAWTThread(java.lang.String applicationName)
        This launches another process to prompt the user to cancel the current activity. If the other process indicates that the user wants to cancel, then this method will call stopAWTThread
        Parameters:
        applicationName - the name to present to the user of the application this might affect.

      • stopAWTThread

        public static void stopAWTThread()
        This uses the unsafe Thread.stop() method on the AWT thread to try to regain control of the application.
